definition: unfounded rumor/to pass on a mistaken belief to others
variant of 訛|讹[e2]
error/false/to extort
to pass on/to spread/to transmit/to infect/to transfer/to circulate/to conduct (electricity)
biography/historical narrative/commentaries/relay station
to spread falsehoods/to increasingly distort the truth/to pile errors on top of errors (idiom)

sentences.english: I"ve heard of some such rumors."
sentences.chinese: 本人听到过一些如许的讹传。

sentences.english: The rumour spread that a new school would be built here.
sentences.chinese: 讹传这里要盖一所新黉舍。

sentences.english: There are really a great many tragedies caused by spreading false news.
sentences.chinese: 以讹传讹造成的悲剧真是太多了。

sentences.english: Gabrielle: Well, I think you're paraphrasing .
sentences.chinese: 我知道你是在以讹传讹。

definition: to spread falsehoods/to increasingly distort the truth/to pile errors on top of errors (idiom)
to add parallels and interpretations (to a story etc)/to develop and embellish/to interpret (often in a strained manner)
rumor
to make far-fetched claims (idiom)/to offer outlandish explanations
error in a text/text corruption
to fabricate/to make sth up/invented
(confirm to be) true/authentic
to make an irrelevant comparison or interpretation (idiom)
lit. view a text and interpret (idiom); to interpret word by word without understanding the meaning/a far-fetched interpretation
popular tradition/folk legend
street stalls/bookshops/in the streets
fabrication relying on nothing (idiom); frame-up
to pass on errors or lies (idiom); the propagation of misconceptions
three men talking makes a tiger (idiom); repeated rumor becomes a fact
a wrong repeated becomes right (idiom); a lie or an error passed on for a long time may be taken for the truth
gossip/hearsay/rumor
